School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University 301 Xuefu Road Zhenjiang 212013 China. Oxygen mobility contributes to HCHO oxidation at room temperature. In this work, oxygen mobilities of the Pt/CeO2 catalysts were controlled by changing ceria shapes to nanorods (CeO2-R), nanocubes (CeO2-C) and nanoparticles (CeO2-P) for HCHO elimination. The smallest ceria crystallite size, the strongest metal-support interaction and the most oxygen vacancy in the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst than those in the Pt/CeO2-C and Pt/CeO2-P catalysts resulted in the greatest redox of surface lattice oxygen and the most oxygen molecules activation at oxygen vacancy sites. These contributed to the most active mobile oxygen and therefore the highest HCHO oxidation performance. In-situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectra (DRIFT) indicated the fastest decomposition of formate at Pt-CeO2 interface on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst because of its highest oxygen mobility. This work illustrated importance of oxygen mobility for efficient HCHO oxidation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Pt/CeO2 Nanorods Nanocubes HCHO oxidation Room temperature 1 Introduction Indoor air pollution is harmful to human, the people who breath pollutants of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and formaldehyde (HCHO) for long hours would get serious diseases of headache and cancer. HCHO is one of the most toxic pollutants causing the diseases, therefore, it is of great significance to eliminate HCHO for the benefit of human health [1–4]. Pt nanoparticle is the most active catalyst for HCHO oxidation than Au, Ag and Pd, developing trace content Pt catalysts for HCHO elimination is of considerable interest in nowadays [5–7]. H. Huang et al. investigated 0.1Pt/TiO2 catalysts, over which 30 ppm HCHO was completely oxidized at room temperature [8]. H. Wu et al. revealed that small Pt size (less than 1 nm) and the strong metal-support interaction in the 0.2Pt/SiO2 catalyst displayed good performance for HCHO elimination [9]. Besides Pt, mobile oxygen including surface lattice oxygen, activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancies and surface hydroxyl groups on support surfaces can also oxidize HCHO [10,11]. Q. Xu et al. suggested that the adsorbed-formaldehyde on CeO2 was oxidized by ceria surface lattice oxygen to formate species, then O2 filled oxygen vacancy forming activated molecular oxygen, which transformed formate to carbonic acid species [12]. L. Nie et al. demonstrated HCHO adsorption by surface hydroxyls on the Pt/TiO2, and proposed HCHO activation on TiO2 and O2 activation on Pt. The corresponding formed OH group and O atom oxidized intermediate CH2-O-HO to formate species [13]. Other works of Pt/HZSM-5 and Pt/Fe3O4 catalysts etc. also revealed importance of mobile oxygen for HCHO oxidation [14,15]. Surface lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancy on ceria are mobile oxygens, metal-support interaction in ceria-based catalysts always promote the oxygen mobilities [16–19]. The advantages make ceria good catalyst for oxidation reactions [20]. It is well known that ceria with different shapes and morphologies have different oxygen mobilities. This is because different crystal planes are exposed on the ceria with different morphologies, the different surface free energy on each planes gives rise to different mobile abilities of oxygen species. For example, surface lattice oxygens of {110} and {100} planes on CeO2 nanorods are more removable than those of {111} plane on CeO2 nanoparticles, leading to the more oxygen vacancies and mobilities [12]. In this manner, the most oxygen vacancy and surface lattice oxygen contributed to the highest HCHO oxidation performance over the Ag/r-CeO2 (nanorods, T90 = 383 K) than over the Ag/p-CeO2 (nanoparticles, T90 =398 K) and Ag/c-CeO2 (nanocubes, T90 = 423 K) [21]. These investigations suggested the important roles of structure and morphology of catalysts for oxygen mobility adjustment [22–24]. In this work, we studied oxygen mobilities of 0.2%Pt/CeO2 catalysts by changing ceria shapes to nanorods (CeO2-R), nanocubes (CeO2-C) and nanoparticles (CeO2-P). The objectives are developing low-cost Pt catalysts for HCHO elimination, and are revealing the dependence between oxygen mobility and HCHO oxidation performance. X-ray power diffraction (XRD), Raman, hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) etc. were applied to analyze oxygen mobilities of the catalysts. The results suggested that the smallest ceria size, the greatest redox of surface lattice oxygen, the most oxygen vacancy and the strongest metal-support interaction in the Pt/CeO2-R showed the most oxygen mobility and thus the highest HCHO oxidation performance [25–27]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2-R and CeO2-C were synthesized by hydrothermal method [28]. A mixture was prepared by adding 40 mL NaOH solution (1.8 mol/L for CeO2-R and 8 mol/L for CeO2-C) to 40 mL Ce(NO3)3 solution (0.5 mol/L). The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and was heated to 373 K for CeO2-R or 453 K for CeO2-C for 20 h. Precipitates were washed, dried at 343 K and calcined at 673 K. CeO2-P was prepared by decomposition of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O at 773 K. Pt/CeO2 was synthesized by depositing H2PtCl6 on CeO2 [29]. CeO2 suspension and H2PtCl6 solution were prepared by dispersing ceria powders and resolving H2PtCl6 to deionized water, respectively. pH of the suspension and the solution were adjusted to 12 by diluted ammonia. The solution was poured into the suspension for stirring overnight. The slurry was washed, dried at 343 K and calcined at 673 K. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Characterizations of inductively coupled plasma atomic absorption spectrometry (ICP), H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XRD, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Pt dispersion, In-situ DRIFTS etc. were given in Supporting Information. 2.3 HCHO oxidation performance evaluation HCHO oxidation performance was measured in a fixed-bed reactor, as described in reference.[10] An apparatus of formaldehyde generator was used to stoichiometrically generate formaldehyde by partial oxidation of methanol. The concentration of formaldehyde was thus preciously controlled by adjusting injection rate of methanol with assistance of micro-pump and flow rate of air by the help of gas flowmeter. Before the measurement, Pt/CeO2 catalyst was treated by 20%H2/N2 at 573 K for 30 min. Gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 150 L/(gh) when measuring HCHO conversion, and was changed to 1500 L/(gh) when conducting kinetic experiments. Conversion, rate and TOF of HCHO were calculated by: (1) X = HCHO inlet − HCHO outlet HCHO inlet * 100 % (2) R BET = F HCHO * X S BET * m cat (3) R Pt = F HCHO * X m cat * w Pt (4) TOF = F HCHO * X m cat * w Pt * D Pt [HCHO] inlet and [HCHO] outlet stand for HCHO concentration (ppm) in the inlet and outlet, respectively. F HCHO is flow rate of HCHO (mol/s), S BET is BET surface area (m2/g), m cat is mass of catalyst (g), w Pt and D Pt are weight percentage (%) and dispersion (%) of Pt. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical and chemical properties of the supports and Pt/CeO2 catalysts ICP (Table S1) showed that 0.17, 0.19 and 0.18 wt% Pt were loaded on the Pt/CeO2-R, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C catalysts, respectively. The loadings were very close to the designed contents of Pt, suggesting that most of the Pt species were deposited on supports of CeO2. The N2 adsorption-desorption and pore size distribution curves of supports ( Fig. 1, A) displayed type IV physisorption isotherms with H1-shaped hysteresis loops, indicating mesopores in the CeO2 materials [30–32]. From the desorption branches, BET areas of the CeO2-R, CeO2-P and CeO2-C were 76.3, 63.2 and 28.7 m2/g, respectively, and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore volumes corresponded to 0.44, 0.21 and 0.23 cm3/g. Adsorption-desorption curves of the Pt/CeO2 catalysts (Fig. 1B) also exhibited type IV isotherms and H1-shaped loops, maintaining the presences of mesopores after Pt dispersion. The largest loop in the Pt/CeO2-R agreed well with its largest BET of 72.8 m2/g and biggest BJH pore volume of 0.42 cm3/g when compared to Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C (Table S1). H2-TPR ( Fig. 2, A) detected reduction peaks at 630, 790 and 780 K for the CeO2-R, CeO2-P and CeO2-C, respectively, which were assigned to reductions of ceria surface lattice oxygen [33,34]. The lowest reduction temperature on the CeO2-R suggested its strongest redox of surface lattice oxygen with hydrogen. When quantifying hydrogen consumptions, 524 μmol/g hydrogen was consumed by surface lattice oxygen on the CeO2-R, slightly higher than 479 and 465 μmol/g on the CeO2-P and CeO2-C, respectively. The highest hydrogen consumption by the CeO2-R suggested its most active oxygen. Reductions of surface lattice oxygen were improved on the Pt/CeO2 catalysts. The peaks at 375–408 K were from co-reductions of PtO2 and the nearby ceria surface lattice oxygen [21]. The surface lattice oxygens that far away from Pt were reduced at 890 and 800 K on the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C, respectively, while the reduction was happened at 550 K on the Pt/CeO2-R [35]. Total hydrogen consumptions were 883, 713 and 696 μmol/g for the Pt/CeO2-R, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C, respectively. The enhancements should be from metal-support interaction between Pt and CeO2. The lowest reduction temperature of surface lattice oxygen and the highest hydrogen consumption on the Pt/CeO2-R suggested the highest active oxygen because of the strongest interaction, and thus the highest oxygen mobility. O2-TPD (Fig. 2B) measured signals of oxygen desorption at 440–460 K in the CeO2 supports, they were assigned to activated molecular oxygen adsorbed at oxygen vacancies of ceria. The biggest desorption area in the CeO2-R suggested its highest oxygen mobility. The desorption was red-shifted to 370, 415 and 445 K in the Pt/CeO2-R, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C catalysts, respectively, because of metal-support interaction. The lowest desorption temperature in the Pt/CeO2-R strongly evidenced the easiest oxygen removal [36]. Another peak at 530 K in the Pt/CeO2-R was from ceria surface lattice oxygen neighboring Pt [27], whilst the desorption was not obvious in the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C. These again indicated the easiest removal of surface lattice oxygen on the Pt/CeO2-R. XRD patterns of the CeO2 supports ( Fig. 3A) detected diffraction peaks that assigned to fluorite ceria with cubic structure. However, the intensities were weaker and the widths were wider for peaks of the CeO2-R, suggesting the smallest ceria crystallite size other others. From the Scherrer equation, ceria crystallite size was 6 nm in the CeO2-R, slightly lower than 10 nm in the CeO2-P and 15 nm in the CeO2-C. As regard to the patterns of the reduced Pt/CeO2 (Fig. 3B), diffraction peaks of ceria were present without signal of Pt, which was due to the low Pt loadings. Due to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ during hydrogen treatment and the formation of oxygen vacancy, the peak intensities in the Pt/CeO2 were weaker than the CeO2 [37], Crystallite sizes of ceria were 5, 10 and 14 nm in the reduced Pt/CeO2-R, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C catalysts, respectively. The sizes were very close to those in supports, suggesting non-occurrences of ceria sintering. Raman of the CeO2 and Pt/CeO2 displayed two signals at 460 and 610 cm−1 (Fig. 3B), which were assigned to F vibration from Ce-O and D vibration from oxygen vacancy in ceria, respectively [38]. The weaker intensity of F vibration in the CeO2-R than in the CeO2-P and CeO2-C, as well as the weaker intensity in the Pt/CeO2-R than in the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C, were associated with the smallest crystallite ceria size of nanorods. The nanorods with smallest crystallite ceria size scattered or adsorbed Raman light, leading to low Raman intensity detected. By normalizing the intensity at 460 cm−1, signals of 610 cm−1 were the strongest in the CeO2-R and Pt/CeO2-R than other counterparts, demonstrating their most oxygen vacancies [18]. Electron spin resonance (ESR) results of the reduced Pt/CeO2 catalysts ( Fig. 4) demonstrated the dependence between oxygen vacancy generation and ceria shape. One peak at g = 1.97 was assigned to Ce3+ with low symmetry and another peak at g = 2.00 was corresponded to an unpaired electron at the site of oxygen vacancy [39,40]. The intensity of the EPR peaks followed the order of Pt/CeO2-R > Pt/CeO2-P > Pt/CeO2-C, which strongly suggested the most Ce3+ and oxygen vacancy in the Pt/CeO2-R. The origination should be closely related to the easiest oxygen removement in the ceria nanorods (H2-TPR, Fig. 2A) because of its smallest crystallite size, most active crystal plane exposure and strongest metal-support interaction. Shapes of the CeO2 and reduced Pt/CeO2 catalysts were displayed in TEM images ( Fig. 5A-F). The morphologies were nanorods, nanoparticles and nanocubes for the CeO2-R, CeO2-P and CeO2-C, respectively. The interplane spacings suggested that the CeO2-R exposed {100} and {110} planes, the CeO2-P displayed {111} planes and the CeO2-C exhibited {100} planes [41]. The length was 50–100 nm and the width was 5 nm in the nanorods, the side-size 20–40 nm in the nanocubes and grain size about 10 nm in the nanoparticles. Pt nanoparticles with size about 5 nm were attached to the CeO2 surfaces. Element mapping results of the Pt/CeO2-R (Fig. 5 G-J) revealed the main presences of Ce and O, and the trace detection of Pt coincided with its low content (EDX, Fig. 5L). Elements survey spectra of the reduced Pt/CeO2 catalysts detected obvious signals of Ce, O and C, while hardly signal of Pt ( Fig. 6, A, Table S2). Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 6B) were fitted to eight peaks, v′ and u′ were assigned to Ce3+ and others were attributed to Ce4+ [42,43]. Ce3+ relative ratio from v ′ + v ′ ∑ v + u were 10.2%, 11.8% and 16.7% on the Pt/CeO2-C, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-R, respectively. The higher Ce3+ ratio on the CeO2-R was associated with the easiest reduction of Ce4+ [34]. Spectra of O 1 s (Fig. 6C) gave two peaks at 528.7 and 531.2 eV, which were surface lattice oxygen (Olat.) on ceria and adsorbed oxygen species (Oad.) at oxygen vacancy sites, respectively. The highest Oad. percentage (27.0%) on the Pt/CeO2-R than those on the Pt/CeO2-P (24.6%) and Pt/CeO2-C (23.8%) indicated the most generation of oxygen vacancy and thus the most mobile oxygen of adsorbed oxygen. Spectra of Pt (Fig. 6D) showed Pt0 signals at 71.7 and 74.8 eV, and Pt2+ signals at 72.1 and 75.5 eV [15,44]. The presence of Pt2+ was due to metallic Pt oxidation before entering to XPS chamber. 3.2 HCHO oxidation performance of the Pt/CeO2 catalysts Room temperature oxidation performance results revealed that HCHO conversions were increased with reaction temperature over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts ( Fig. 7A). The Pt/CeO2-R catalyst exhibited the highest performance, followed by the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C. This indicated the close relationship between HCHO performance and ceria shape. The originations could be from both factors of Pt nanoparticles and CeO2 supports in the catalysts. Concerning the Pt nanoparticles, although sizes of Pt on the catalysts were identical (TEM), the highest metallic Pt content (Table S2) on the Pt/CeO2-R (70.3%) than those on the Pt/CeO2-P (67.5%) and Pt/CeO2-C (66.6%) would provide the most Pt atoms for O2 activation. In view of the CeO2 supports, the biggest BET area of the CeO2-R provided the most sites for HCHO activation, the strongest redox (H2-TPR), the most activated molecular oxygen (O2-TPD) and the most oxygen vacancy (Raman, EPR) on the CeO2-R gave rise to the highest mobile oxygens of surface lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst. Performance of the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst was also tested at harsh conditions of 100 ppm HCHO and moistures (relative humidity RH=50%, 80%). The results (Fig. 7B) showed that HCHO conversion was higher under moisture condition than under dry condition, and the higher RH leaded to the higher conversion. This suggested the positive effect of moisture. The CO2 formation (Fig. 7C) and the unconverted HCHO (Fig. 7D) in the outlet indicated that chemical oxidation was mainly occurred while physical adsorption was minorly happened in the HCHO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst. In one literature, Au/CeO2 catalyst was reported more active for HCHO oxidation in moisture condition than in dry condition, which was postulated from the more oxidatively hydroxyl groups from moisture [45]. In the current case, although moisture RH was up to 50%− 80%, condensation of gaseous H2O was not happened because GHSV was very high. Adsorption of gaseous H2O generated hydroxyl groups on ceria. The mobile oxygens from surface lattice oxygen, activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancy and hydroxyl group on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst contributed to HCHO conversion. Stability results suggested that HCHO conversions were progressively decreased in the initial 8 h at 1 ppm HCHO ( Fig. 8A), after that the conversions were maintained at about 91%, 81% and 76% over the Pt/CeO2-R, Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C catalysts, respectively. The initial performance decay should be associated with the inter-reaction between HCHO+O2 and catalyst surface, which made the surface more and more stabilize. The result confirmed the highest stable oxidation performance over the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst. Moisture-resistance of the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst revealed that HCHO conversions were kept at 51% and 46% at RH of 80% and 50%, respectively, when using 100 ppm HCHO (Fig. 8B), showing excellent HCHO elimination efficiency under high moisture condition. Intrinsic rates of HCHO over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts were compared by specific rates and TOFs of HCHO at 298 K. The results (Table S3) showed that specific rate was 2.39 nmol/(m2ˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst when normalizing BET surface area, which was higher than 2.01 nmol/(m2ˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-C catalyst and 1.90 nmol/(m2ˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-P catalyst. This suggested that HCHO oxidation performance was dependent on BET areas of the CeO2 supports. Due to surface lattice oxygen and surface oxygen vacancies were on CeO2 surface, this dependence might closely relate to the oxygen mobility of the catalysts. Meantime, specific rates were 102.2 mmol/(gPtˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-R, which was higher than 60.1 mmol/(gPtˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-P and 42.6 mmol/(gPtˑs) on the Pt/CeO2-C when normalizing Pt mass loading. This indicated that Pt influenced oxygen mobility because of metal-support interaction. Although the TOFs in this study were lower than those of the 0.2Pt/SiO2, they were comparable to the 0.3Pt/TS-1, 0.3Pt/Silicalite-1 and Ag/CeO2 catalysts. 3.3 HCHO oxidation mechanism over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts HCHO oxidation mechanism over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts were studied by In-situ DRIFTs. For the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst ( Fig. 9A-B), dioxymethylene (DOM, H2CO2) was observed at 933–962 (γa,CH2), 1044–1149 (γas,CH2) and 1458 cm−1 (ωCH2), OH groups were displayed at 3545–3670 cm−1 [45,46]. The species were suggested from HCHO activation by ceria lattice oxygen. Bands at 1356, 1543 and 1630 cm−1 were from symmetric (νs) and asymmetric stretching (νas) of COO [12]. νs and νas of C-H in formate were measured at 2800, 2869 and 3020 cm−1 [47]. The appearances indicated that DOM was oxidized by surface lattice oxygen of Pt/CeO2-R catalysts to formate species. Linear and bridge CO adsorbed on Pt were observed at 2084 and 1860 cm−1, respectively, and linear CO adsorbed on Pt2+ was appeared at 1980 cm−1 [48]. The signals suggested that CO might be from formate decomposition, and was then oxidized to CO2 (2357 cm−1) by ceria surface lattice oxygen [48]. CO2 signal under O2-absent condition was slightly stronger than those under O2-present condition, which indicated that CO2 were mostly desorbed and the activated molecular oxygen exhibited positive effect for HCHO oxidation. With the temperature increased to 373 K, signals of DOM, formate species and CO were progressively decreased, suggesting that oxidative abilities of the lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen were enhanced at higher temperature. DRIFTs of the Pt/CeO2-C (Fig. 9C-D) and Pt/CeO2-P (Fig. 9E-F) showed some similarities to those of the Pt/CeO2-R. However, the lower intensities of 932–970, 1052–1175 and 1450–1460 cm−1 indicated the fewer formation of DOM, the weaker intensities of 1990–1993 and 2020–2080 cm−1 inferred the less adsorbed CO, and the stronger intensities of 1393–1397 and 1631–1636 cm−1 suggested the more preservation of formate. These indicated the slower decomposition of formate on the Pt/CeO2-C and Pt/CeO2-P than on the Pt/CeO2-R, confirming the highest oxidative abilities of surface lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen on ceria nanorods. From the DRIFT results, mechanism of HCHO oxidation could be tentatively proposed ( Fig. 10). Activation of HCHO was happened on ceria surface, forming intermediate DOM. The DOM were oxidized by mobile oxygen (surface lattice oxygen, activated molecular oxygen at ceria oxygen vacancy and/or hydroxyl group) to formate. The formate species migrated to interface of Pt-CeO2, and were decomposed to CO adsorbed on Pt nanoparticles. CO was then oxidized by mobile oxygen to CO2, which was desorbed from catalyst surface to bulk gas. The highest oxidative abilities of surface lattice oxygen, activated molecular oxygen at ceria oxygen vacancy and hydroxyl group on the Pt/CeO2-R than those on the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C leaded to the fastest formate decomposition and thus the highest performance. 3.4 Discussion on the oxygen mobility for HCHO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts Various works have demonstrated size and shape influences of catalysts for catalytic reactions, this is because the size and shape determine the exposure of crystal planes, giving different redox of surface lattice oxygen, formation amount of oxygen vacancy and strength of metal-support interaction, which result in differences of oxygen mobility [49,50]. In the current work, 6 nm CeO2-R nanorods, 8 nm CeO2-P nanoparticles and 15 nm CeO2-C nanocubes were synthesized. The materials exhibited shape-dependent properties of redox, oxygen vacancy and metal-support interaction in bare oxides and Pt/CeO2 catalysts, which gave shape-dependent oxygen mobility. The properties played vital roles in HCHO elimination because intermediates can be oxidized by surface lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancies on ceria, as well as formate decomposition at Pt-CeO2 boundaries [51]. Among the ceria supports and Pt/CeO2 catalysts, H2-TPR profiles of the CeO2-R and Pt/CeO2-R demonstrated the most removable surface lattice oxygen, O2-TDP indicated the most desorption of oxygen molecules at oxygen vacancies, Raman and EPR confirmed the most generation of oxygen vacancies. These leaded to the highest mobile oxygen on the nanorods catalyst. The origination was associated with the exposure of most active {100} and {110} planes on the CeO2-R, while only {100} planes on the CeO2-C and less active {111} planes on the CeO2-P. The {110} plane has the highest surface energy than the {100} and {111} planes, lattice oxygen was most removable and oxygen vacancy was most generated. HCHO activation and formate decomposition on catalyst surface are important steps for finishing the whole oxidation. From in-situ DRIFT, the stronger intensities of DOM, the weaker intensities of formate species on the Pt/CeO2-R than on the Pt/CeO2-P and Pt/CeO2-C suggested the most activation of HCHO, the strongest oxidation of DOM and the fastest decomposition of formate. These were contributed from the highest oxidative ability of surface lattice oxygen and activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancy on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, 0.2 wt% Pt/CeO2 catalysts were synthesized by changing CeO2 to nanorods, nanoparticles and nanocubes for HCHO elimination. Physicochemical properties of ceria size, redox and oxygen vacancy etc. revealed the greatest redox behavior of surface lattice oxygen, the most formation of oxygen vacancy and the strongest metal-support interaction in the Pt/CeO2-R than those in other catalysts. The most mobile oxygens including surface lattice oxygen, activated molecular oxygen at oxygen vacancy and hydroxyl group were proposed to display the highest HCHO oxidation performance over the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst. The work evidenced the significances of oxygen mobility control by changing ceria morphologies for efficient HCHO oxidation over ceria-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen mobility contributes to HCHO oxidation at room temperature. In this work, oxygen mobilities of the Pt/CeO2 catalysts were controlled by changing ceria shapes to nanorods (CeO2-R), nanocubes (CeO2-C) and nanoparticles (CeO2-P) for HCHO elimination. The smallest ceria crystallite size, the strongest metal-support interaction and the most oxygen vacancy in the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst than those in the Pt/CeO2-C and Pt/CeO2-P catalysts resulted in the greatest redox of surface lattice oxygen and the most oxygen molecules activation at oxygen vacancy sites. These contributed to the most active mobile oxygen and therefore the highest HCHO oxidation performance. In-situ diffused reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectra (DRIFT) indicated the fastest decomposition of formate at Pt-CeO2 interface on the Pt/CeO2-R catalyst because of its highest oxygen mobility. This work illustrated importance of oxygen mobility for efficient HCHO oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Room temperature HCHO oxidation over the Pt/CeO2 catalysts with different oxygen mobilities by changing ceria shapes
